reason: The prover's 'REVISED APPROACH' contains a logical error that is then correctly self-caught but the analysis is confused. The prover writes: 'f(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i) (since p(lambda_i) = 0), and the signs of p'(lambda_i) alternate... So f has at least n-1 real roots... Since f has degree n, it has exactly n roots total, so at most 1 non-real root. Since non-real roots come in conjugate pairs, there are either 0 or 2 non-real roots, but we can have at most 1, so there are 0 non-real roots.' The prover then catches the error: f has COMPLEX coefficients since c in C^-, so non-real roots need NOT come in conjugate pairs. GOOD -- this self-correction is honest. However, the prover fails to note that even the intermediate claim 'f(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i) and signs alternate' is incomplete: while signs of p'(lambda_i) do alternate (standard property of polynomials with simple real roots), the claim that f(w) = p'(w) - nc*p(w) has a sign change between consecutive lambda_i depends on f being real-valued at the lambda_i, which it IS (since p(lambda_i) = 0 so f(lambda_i) = p'(lambda_i) is real). So f does have n-1 real roots. But f has degree n with complex leading coefficient -nc, so the n-th root need not be real or come with a conjugate partner. The n-th root is IN FACT in C^+ when Im(c) < 0 (equivalently Im(nc) < 0). This is the content of the selection principle, and it CAN be proved by tracking the argument of the leading coefficient. The prover did not reach this conclusion.
